Title: CYP Specialist Emotional Health & Wellbeing Service
Description:
This is a Contract Award Notice to communicate that on 24th June 2020, the Collaborative Commissioning Forum for NHS Castle Point & Rochford, NHS Southend and NHS Mid Essex Clinical Commissioning Groups made a decision to award contracts for the provision of an emotional resilience and person-centered counselling service (the "CYP Specialist Emotional Health & Wellbeing Service") for children and young people in Castle Point and Rochford, Southend and Mid Essex. Contracts were entered into by the CCGs with three voluntary sector organisations (South East & Central Essex Mind, Open Door and Kids Inspire) for a period of 6 months commencing 1st August 2020, with an additional 6-month extension period provision. 

The CCG is publishing this Contract Award Notice in the Contracts Finder in accordance with the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 for spend above £25,000.The Services in scope of this Contract Award Notice fall within 'social and other specific services' within the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 (the Regulations) but the aggregate total contract value of £222,699 does not exceed the current threshold of £663,540.
Contact Name: NHS Castlepoint and Rochford Clinical Commissioning Group

Title: Disability Short Breaks - Summertime Activities
Description: Kingston upon Hull City Council (the Authority) invites qualified and interested suppliers to tender for the provision of a contract for: Summertime Activities. The Authority is conducting the procurement using the open procedure (non EU), as required by the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 (SI 2015/102) (PCR 2015).  The Disability Short Breaks - Summertime Activities is a specialist service to support disabled children, young people, families and carers. The Summertime Activities will provide a community based summer activity programme which will promote fun and friendship through positive play experiences for children and young people whilst giving parents and carers a short break. The DSB - Summertime Activities is part of the overall Children's Disability Service for Hull which aims to provide a range of short breaks service provision to promote the wellbeing of disabled children, young people, families and carers. Children and young people will have improved emotional well-being through increased opportunities for play and social interaction; • children and young people will have improved self confidence and self esteem; • children and young people will be supported to have fun, learn new skills and enhance their independence; • children and young people will have increased opportunities to participate in play and leisure opportunities alongside their disabled and non disabled peers. • children and young people will experience positive time away from their parents, carers and families. • parents, carers and siblings will have a short break, building family strength and resilience and preventing pressure and crisis. • siblings will have increased opportunity to spend quality time with their parents or carers. The Authority proposes to enter into Contract for a period of 3 years with the successful Tenderer (Service Provider), with an option to extend for a period or periods of up to a maximum of 12 months. Such extension will be at the discretion of the Authority and subject to satisfactory performance and monitoring. The budget available for the duration of this contract is approximately £270,000.00. The price will be fixed for the duration of the contract. The anticipated service commencement date is 28 February 2019. The Authority envisages that the staff working on the current service shall transfer to the Service Provider or its subcontractors, under the Transfer of Undertakings (Protection of Employment) Regulations 2006 (SI 2006/246) (TUPE).
Supplier [Name|Address|Ref type|Ref Numb: [KIDS|182 Chanterlands Avenue. Hull. HU5 4DJ|NONE||Yes|No]

Title: Support for parents of children with additional needs to improve family emotional wellbeing
Description:
Kingston upon Hull City Council (the Authority) invites qualified and interested suppliers to tender for the provision of a contract for: Support for parents of children with additional needs to improve family emotional wellbeing . The Authority is conducting the procurement using the open procedure, as required by the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 (SI 2015/102) (PCR 2015).

The targeted support for parents of children with additional needs service is part of the Targeted level of provision within the HeadStart Hull Delivery Model. Targeted support offers a menu of targeted interventions which school and community based services can access for children, young people and families. Targeted interventions provide provision where a need is identified which cannot be addressed by the referring service. 

The Authority proposes to enter into Contract for a maximum period of 33 months with the successful Tenderer (Service Provider), no extension will be granted to this contract.

The anticipated budget available for the duration of this contract is approximately £206,079.00. Any bid that exceeds this value shall be treated as non-compliant and eliminated form further process.

The anticipated service commencement date is 8 October 2018.

The Authority envisages that the staff working on the current service shall transfer to the Service Provider or its subcontractors, under the Transfer of Undertakings (Protection of Employment) Regulations 2006 (SI 2006/246) (TUPE).

Description:
Organisations must register their interest against the advert on the South East Business Portal in order to receive any changes or notifications issued by the Council during this tender process.

Targeted schemes form part of the Council's Tier 2 provision and support the early intervention work for children and young people (up to the age of 18) with disabilities, including complex needs, and their families. 

The contract will be divided and commissioned in two lots; each lot providing for one age range. Prospective tenderers will be able to bid for one or both lots.

Title: Disagreement Resolution Services, Mediation Advice and Mediation Services for Children and Young People aged 0 ? 25 years with Special Educational Needs and Disabilities
Description: Nottinghamshire County Council is leading on a tender process to procure a framework agreement for disagreement resolution services, mediation advice and mediation services. There are 8 other local authorities across the East Midlands who are interested in using this framework agreement, namely: Derby City Derbyshire Leicester City Leicestershire Lincolnshire  Northamptonshire - information required  Nottingham City - Information required Rutland The services to be commissioned will be focused on children and young people aged 0 - 25 years, who have special educational needs and/or disabilities. The provision will be targeted at the parents and carers of these children and young people, and the young people in their own right.  In addition to the 9 local authorities of the East Midlands, other interested parties may include schools and colleges for the disagreement resolution service; whilst health services and other public bodies across the region may be interested parties for all 3 lots. For the purposes of this contract interested parties comprising of schools and colleges are referred to throughout this document as indirect customers. Interested bodies such as health and other public bodies will come under the definition of contracting bodies and as such will be able to call-off services directly.  The East Midlands region's detailed requirements are defined in Part 3 of this document - Specification. The framework agreement will be divided into 3 lots: Lot 1 - Disagreement Resolution Services (multi-provider lot). Lot 2 - Mediation Advice (single provider lot) Lot 3 - Mediation Services (multi-provider lot) This is a competitive procurement conducted in accordance with the open procedure under the Public Contracts Regulations 2006. The Council will not negotiate any terms of the ITT (including the Contract). Consequently, it is vital that Bidders raise any points of clarification before the time and date referred to in the timetable at paragraph 3.3. Should the Bidder find discrepancies in, or omissions from, the ITT, they should communicate this via the Portal. Bidders must comply with the terms of this ITT and should read the entire document carefully and take any independent financial or legal advice, if necessary as early as possible in the process.

Title: 686/2018 Special Educational Needs & Disability Information, Advice & Support Service (SENDIASS) & Mediation/Dispute Resultion Service
Description:
Croydon Council is seeking to engage contractors for the provision of Special Educational Needs and Disability Information, Advice and Support Service (SENDIASS) (Lot One) and Mediation/Dispute Resolution Service (Lot Two).
To support children and young people with SEND and their families who may be seeking information, advice and support and provide a mediation and dispute resolution service between families and the Council.As set out in the SEND Code of Practice it is be practice that these two services should not be provided by the same supplier in order to ensure maximum objectivity across the two distinct areas of service provision. The Council will seek to award a contract in the form of separate lots. The award of each lot will be awarded to different providers. PROVIDERS WILL BE PERMITTED TO APPLY FOR ONE LOT ONLY. 

Lot One - a single supplier to deliver a Special Educational Needs and Disability Information, Advice & Support Service (SENDIASS) (Lot 1) = £75,000 per annum
Lot Two - a single supplier to deliver a SEND Mediation and dispute resolution service - (Lot  2) = £25,000 per annum

Title: short breaks and other support services for disabled children and young people and their families (SP/
Description:
Short breaks are services that local authorities have a statutory duty to provide to assist parents and others who provide care for disabled children and young people.  This enables parents and carers to continue to care for their children or do this more effectively. Short breaks not only provide a break for parents and carers, but can also lead to a better quality of care being provided. This results in better outcomes not only for the disabled child, but for the whole family. This includes reduced family breakdown and reduced likelihood of requests for residential school provision. The provision of short breaks also supports the Council's approach to meeting the needs of children with complex needs and reducing the need for high cost out of borough placements.
The service will be tendered in two lots
Lot 1Group Based Short Breaks 
Lot 2 Outreach Short Breaks 

the contract/s (both lots) is for an initial 
period of 3 years with the option of 2 extensions each of one year at the sole discretion of the council.

Title: Short Breaks Service for Disabled Children
Description:
The Government and the Authority want all children to have the best start in life and the on-going support that they and their families need to fulfill their potential and maximise their well-being. Children with a disability are less likely to achieve their potential in a range of areas as compared to their non-disabled peers. Improving their outcomes, allowing them to benefit from equality of opportunity and increasing their involvement and inclusion in society and mainstream services will reduce social inequality and allow communities to benefit from the contribution that disabled children and their families can make; harnessing their talent and fostering tolerance, diversity and difference.
The Authority wants to work in partnership with children and young people; their parents and carers; the Authority's statutory and non-statutory partners and the provider market to deliver a higher volume of high quality, diverse and creative support for children with a disability. This will focus on delivering improved outcomes, improving the wellbeing of service users and providing a respite opportunity for carers.

Notice Identifier: 1920-0180 - One to One (1:1) Support, Day Opportunities and Activities Framework for People with Dis
Title: Award of One to One (1:1) Support, Day Opportunities and Activities Framework for People with Disabilities
Description: One to one (1:1) support, day opportunities and activities are important parts of our local offer for people with disabilities. We want to formalise our relationships with providers of these services who are committed to delivering high quality, flexible and personalised services to meet identified local needs. Establishing a framework agreement from which to purchase these services is an opportunity to increase the range of services available for people to choose from and to drive innovation, value for money and an increased focus on outcomes. This framework agreement is intended to develop a wider range of local services. Providers will therefore ensure, where applicable, that the service has activity bases in Islington or within a suitable distance to minimise transport time and transport costs.

Title: C20190246 - Ofcom Market Research Framework
Description:
Ofcom's Market Research team commissions primary research services for a range of teams across the organisation, including Consumer Policy, Spectrum Policy Group, Competition Group and the Content and Strategy teams. Examples of our work can be located in the Market Research section of the Ofcom website:

https://www.ofcom.org.uk/research-and-data

There are four Market Research Lots in the new framework for the provision of standard market research services, each of which relate to a broad area of standard research expertise; quantitative, qualitative, omnibus and online panel research. If Ofcom has a specialist or niche market research service requirement we may choose to commission that through the framework, or we may choose to commission it via an open Invitation to Tender Process, by inviting specialist suppliers to bid.

At this stage of the process, Applicants are invited to express an interest in providing standard market research services to Ofcom in one or more of these lots. Applicants that pass this initial assessment will be invited to take part in the second stage of the tender.  If successful in the second stage of the tender, they will be added as Tenderers to the framework agreement for a particular Lot(s).

The Lots under this framework will be:
Lot 1 - Quantitative Research
Lot 2- Qualitative Research
Lot 3 - Face to Face omnibus research
Lot 4 - Online panel research

Title: 18-086: De-commissioning / Outsourcing of Dalton Childrens Centre
Description:
Rotherham Metropolitan Borough Council are inviting bids from providers who are able to provide Ofsted Registered high quality early education places to 2, 3 and 4 year old's plus sustainable childcare places of 3 hours to meet needs in the Dalton area.  
The Early Help Strategy 2016-19 includes proposals to retain designated children Centre status for Thrybergh/Dalton Children's Centre but to re-locate the delivery staff to an alternative base.  
The building and the running of the existing day care are service is therefore being offered as a tendering opportunity to external organisations who think they may be able to provide this service.

Title: Who Dares Works Onsite Childcare
Description:
Active Plus Community Interest Company wishes to bring an onsite, flexible childcare provider into the Who Dares Works partnership in order to help overcome barriers to parents' participation in the Who Dares Works project and to support its Equal Opportunities and Gender Equality Action Plan. The service must be delivered onsite or near to Who Dares Works delivery in community-based venues across the whole of West Cornwall and be flexible enough to cater for fluctuating numbers of children according to the number of participants attending. There may be occasions where service requests are made at short notice, but most of the activities within the project are scheduled in advance.  

Who Dares Works is a project funded by the European Social Fund and the National Lottery through the Big Lottery Fund. It is led and managed by Active Plus Community Interest Company and delivered through a partnership of 17 social enterprises. 

The aim of Who Dares Works is to help and inspire people aged 18 and over who are not working, who live in West Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly and who have a range of needs or barriers to overcome, to reconnect with education, training and work. The project is funded until 31 December 2019. Delivery is likely to finish by 31 October 2019.

Specific requirements and additional project information is set out in the application pack available from communities@activeplus.org.uk
Contact Address 1: Active Plus, Health and Wellbeing Innovation Centre

Title: Creche Provision
Description:
Sheffield's Multi Agency Support Team (MAST) are implementing a roll out of parenting programmes across the city and require crèche provision for these from April 2019. These range from one off discussion groups and seminars to longer specialist parenting courses. To reduce the barriers to parents being able to access these programmes we require high quality crèche provision to provide childcare whilst parents are taking part in the various aspects of parenting.  

The requirement for MAST is detailed below for indicative purposes.  This may be subject to change and some flexibility is required due to the nature of the requirement. For example numbers of children attending crèche may go up or down with little notice. This would require the provider to be flexible with the amount of crèche workers provided.

We may pre-book a term in advance with all the dates and then may need to reduce the number of crèche workers a week before if the provision needed is lower, for example.

Lot 3 - Learning Mats

The framework agreement/contract has the option to extend for up to a further 24 months. The total estimated value stated includes the option period.

An eAuction process may be used to award subsequent call off contracts following the reopening of competition among the parties to the Framework Agreement.

As a Central Purchasing Body as defined by the EU Procurement Directive 2014/24/EU, the Framework Agreement is open for use by Public Bodies (defined https://www.espo.org/ESPO/media/Documents/FAQs/ESPO-s_powers_to_trade__website_-2016-12-22.pdf) that also fall into one of the following classifications of user throughout all administrative regions of the UK: Local Authorities; Educational Establishments (including Academies); Central Government Departments and Agencies; Police, Fire & Rescue and Coastguard Emergency Services; NHS and HSC Bodies, including Ambulance Services; Registered Charities; Registered Social Landlords; or any public body established by or under the Scotland Act 1998 or any Act of the Scottish Parliament. Details of the classification of end user establishments and geographical areas is available on: http://www.espo.org/About-us-%281%29/FAQs/Legal

Title: Supply and Installation of a Magnetometry Test Bench Including Head Phantoms to the University of Birmingham
Description:
Supply and Installation of a Magnetometry Test Bench Including Head Phantoms to the University of Birmingham

Equipment for visual and auditory stimulation, button press device as well as eye-tracker for monitoring the eye movements of the test-persons. 

Visual stimulation: we require a visual projector with a >1000Hz refresh rate.

Auditory stimulation: the stimulation needs to be MEG compatible.

Control pad kid: The device must be MEG compatible, i.e. using optical fibers. 

Eye-tracking: the eye-tracker must operate at a fast sampling frequency (>1000 Hz) in order to detect micro-saccades. 

Furthermore it must be integrated with the projector such that visual stimulation can be coupled to eye-movements.

The devices above must be integrated in order to work together

Overall budget for this item is up to £117,000 (VAT EXEMPTION)

This project may be funded by the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) or;
-	European Structural and Investment Fund (ESIF) or;
-	Research Councils UK (RCUK), the strategic partnership of the UK's seven Research Councils.

Title: VegPower - Seasonal Vegetable Campaign
Description:
The current Covid-19 situation has impacted the food and farming industry dramatically and government has been called upon to offer support in these unprecedented times. In order to provide that support, we need to act quickly to on board a partner who can offer strong connections and industry knowledge, as well as deliver best value for money and meet our campaign objectives.  
VegPower CIC are a non-for-profit organisation focused on encouraging kids and families to eat more vegetables. They run programmes for schools and have developed good relationships with celebrity chefs and nutritionists who usually support them with videos on social media. As such, they are the only industry-wide organisation with capacity to meet our brief, provide the connections and channels for our planned campaign activity.
We will work with colleagues in Public Health England to ensure the project achieves Value for Money and Return on Investment, adhering to our campaign's rigorous evaluation standards. We will be taking on board previous campaign activity to procure the best coverage available and to ensure fair costs are obtained.
Additional Text: Please note that Defra procurement uses an E-tendering system for Procurement activities.  This is currently provided by Bravo Solutions.   To access appropriate tendering and contractual documents, please access the E-Tendering portal at https://defra.bravosolution.co.uk", ensuring that your registration includes "Defra".  If you have any problems with this system, please contact Bravo on their telephone helpline number 0800 368 4850 or by emailing them at help@bravosolution.co.uk. "

Title: Provision of Technical Outsourcing for App and Website Development
Description:
Launchpad is an innovative incubator of high-growth, high-tech companies based in Cornwall. This procurement is for a team based within the Launch-Pad incubation programme, who are developing an app for the attraction sector to enable the tracking and monitoring of visitors. We intend to procure technical outsourcing for this incubating team, and this RFQ specifies the requirements for such quotes.

Launchpad is a pre-seed incubator, which recruits individuals into complementary teams of 4. We bring together business people, software developers and digital media creatives to build new high-growth companies. These founding teams spend 2-3 months selecting the concept of their product based on market research, engagement with partners of the programme, and sometimes early user engagement. The rest of a year is spent building a business and a product to meet the market need that they have identified. At the end of the year, the teams seek investment to take their businesses to market, and grow at a high rate.
The programme has identified that the team in question does not have the relevant technical expertise in the team.  The team has created a strong business case for the app, and have lined up an attraction to trial the app with. The team have developed the user stories required for the app and scoped the outsourcing required for a proof of concept app. It is our belief that this team requires technical outsourcing to enable them to grow the business.	Build an application to work on iOS and Android mobile phones that can track, monitor and predict where visitors will be at an attraction. The app will provide an interactive map of the core exhibits for visitors to engage with and personalised trails and offers to shift visitor flow. For example, a visitor with children would be sent an in-app notification offering discounted kids lunch boxes at 11am to avoid the peak rush at 12noon for lunch in the canteen.	Build an analytics dashboard optimised for the Google Chrome browser only, for the attraction staff to track visitors. This will be visible via an interactive heat map showing where crowded areas are. The dashboard will also allow the Launch-Pad team to manually send personalised offers to visitors to shift visitor flow
Attachments: 1386Launch-pad Technical Outsourcing for App and Website Development.docx
Additional Text:
Stage 1 - Expression of Interest and signing of Non-disclosure Agreement (NDA)

If you wish to participate in this tender you will need to register an interest and complete a non-disclosure agreement.  Once signed and returned, the full detailed specification of the software can be issued (the detailed requirements of the software are confidential to Falmouth University).   Please be aware that to proceed to the Stage 2 of the process, the NDA must be signed and returned in line with the timeframes as set out in section 4 of this document. 
To register your interest and to receive the NDA for electronic signing, send an e-mail to ben.sewell@falmouth.ac.uk; upon completion of electronic signatures the requirements will be sent to the bidder.
